answers.answer: Hi vprrchk!  Sounds like you have a neat little system going.  In my own circumstance, my daughter doesn't show any signs, typically, when she's low, so the only way to know where her bg is at is by testing her.  Testing is still the only accurate way of knowing for sure what someone's bg is.  I wouldn't recommend this method as the only way to check someone's bg as not everyone is the same and when dealing with a low bg, you really should know for sure.  Thanks for writing in to us, and I hope that you visit our site again.

Hi,I was intrigued by your "password trick", and thought I would try it with my son. I won't be relying on it at this stage, but I thought, since it has worked for you and your dad, it might be a fair "indicator" of low bg levels in my son. I spend much of the night, touching him for that sweaty feel to the skin, lifting his limbs or pushing him gently across the bed to test for muscle tone and responses. Since, when he is "low" according to a glucometer during sleep, he readily responds to requests to take glucose, jellybeans, etc, presumably he might also respond to a request for the "password", despite being asleep, and thus aiding the assessment of his current status.Thanks for the tip. Any others?JJ's mom

Hi again, Vprrchk,What a clever mom you have!!  I'm the diabetic in our home and I'm going to try this trick with my hubby.  Sometimes I know he "thinks" I'm low and this will be a handy additional way for us to quickly signal that there's a concern.I almost always have my testing stuff with me and yet I can envision many situations where a discrete bit o' code talk could get us quickly into "test my bg" mode.Thanks for sharing this tip!

Hi vprrchk,Just to put my two cents in I agree with gg that testing is very important, but what a great idea to have a code word for an intital sign of a low coming on. How very smart. It never cease's to amaze me that no matter how long we have been dealing with diabetes the people posting in this forum can teach us so much with their own experiences. Please keep coming back.Thank you,dm

Hi everyone,I, of course, was not meaning to say not to check your bg.  I know that there are often times when checking your bg would be inappropriate, or you don't have your machine around, so using the password would be helpful.  Anyway, I hope it helps everyone out (even if it helps one person it is worth it :)~vprrchk
What a good idea!  If you are low, you might come up with something close to the password, but not the actual word!  Good "screening" tool.

question: Hello,This isn't really a question, but a little trick I have learned from my mom.  My dad had been a diabetic since he was 3 years old, zoom some odd number into the future and then he married my mom.  My mom tells me all the time about the things she would have to do for him, rolling over at night and touching his arm to see if he was sweating (a major sign of low bg for him), force him to eat when he was low, among other things.  When I developed diabetes she started thinking that there has to be a better way to see if someone's bg is low while you're out.  So...she came up with a brilliant idea.  What she did was tell both of us a very common word (for us it was "answering machine") and that is our "password."  It works every single time!!  All someone has to do that is around is ask "What's the password?"  And let me tell you (it's funny when I look at it, but not very funny to her, lol) no matter how hard I or my dad tried, we could not come up with the correct word.  Sometimes I would say "cell phone" or "phone" or "fax," but never "answering machine."  Anyway, I thought I would pass this along and see if it works for anyone else.~vprrchk
